txt.en: 'Because they are. This city is a part of Rohan, whether you like it or not.'
'You speak in ideals. Not everything in this life can be ideal.'
'Anyone who murders another within this city should face justice for their crimes.'
'You are fools. Your pride and greed will usher your doom.'
Instance: Liberating Woodhurst
'You would be lying to me and everyone here if you tell me greed is not the inspiration for your plan.'
'Woodhurst, and the Stonedeans as a whole, would be stronger if we unite our people under our own banner.'
'Herubrand will hear of what happened here today. He will also want to hear what you have proposed.'
'Both Rohirrim and Dunlending have lived in this city in relative peace, and we will again.'
'Those are lies, and you are a fool if you think otherwise.'
'If the city guard received ideal funding, there would be more I could do to protect the people of this city.'
'The war between the White Hand and Rohirrim does not have to include the Stonedeans.'
'The White Hand threat in Brockbridge is a threat to all of us.'
'And Saruman views the Stonedeans as part of his enemy, so we should view him the same.'
'You are a fool. It appears Gifemund and Elda were right, and you are no longer fit to be captain of the guard here in Woodhurst.'
'Have you not heard the rumours? Rohirrim have resorted to eating their Dunlending captives, sometimes alive I am told...'
'It is quite clear who is winning this war, is it not? Rohan will fall, and then what?'
'Quiet your lap-dog, Gifemund. This matter is between us.'
'Anyone who deems Woodhurst their home, and is respectful of their neighbour is an important part of this city.'
'I will leave without trouble, but know this:'
'Your lackey should know about my funding problem. And I see two of my former men are with you, now.'
'You and I have a lot to discuss...'
'Your support is appreciated, Calin. Thurferth has done more harm than good of late.'
'Is it not your duty to deliver justice to everyone in Woodhurst, even those in lower Woodhurst?'
'Follow me. We can watch with a better view from over here.'
'I will return to sift through the ashes and rebuild this great city for the Dunlendings, who deserve to live here.'
'You are naive. War will come here, whether we invite it or not.'
'Is that also true of the Dunlendings exiled to lower Woodhurst?'
'That is yet to be seen. The throne here belongs to Herubrand.'
'And where is he to claim it? He has forsaken the troubles of Woodhurst to see to those in Brockbridge...'
'Are those men from lower Woodhurst not the ones attacking others within the city?'
'Why are you so quick to call the White Hand our enemy?'
'I am out-numbered, and cannot convince you to see reason.'
'That is the point. You are not considering them men of Woodhurst.'
'The time has come for you to step down, Thurferth. Your failing our people is evident in how many are leaving.'
'This is not about profits. This is about the safety of our people, and doing what is right.'
'I care not that Rohirrim are leaving Woodhurst; that is their decision.'
'Yes, of course I would profit. That benefits not just me, but the Stonedeans and its people would profit.'
'I wish to speak with him when I can. Is he returning soon?'
'Would you not profit from your plan, by selling your ore to both the White Hand and Rohirrim?'
'Or those banished to Dunland long ago?'
'Thurferth, you and your men are banished from this city. Pack up your belongings and be gone by dawn.'
'That is right, most of the people have decided who they will follow.'
'We should side with Saruman now before it is too late.'
